12.text:
Prime Minister: "Ambassadors, Ladies and Gentlemen, Chief
Rabbi, a very warm welcome to you in your

24.text:
new role. And Freda, thank you for that very
very kind introduction. It seems as you've

32.text:
just pointed out that maybe I didn't meet
an inspiring Ninety year old back in January,

40.text:
but I certainly have today. So Shanah Tovah,
and a happy Ninetieth birthday for last week.

54.text:
You mentioned Prime Minister's Questions,
and it was so good to be able to say something

62.text:
useful and meaningful in that extraordinary
half hour. It is easily the most miserable

69.text:
half hour of my week. It has one and only
one redeeming feature that I've thought of

76.text:
over the last seven years, and that was when
I was in New York with Mayor Bloomberg and

82.text:
we walked down the street and everyone came
up to the mayor and praised him for his work.

87.text:
"Mike you're doing a fantastic job." "Mike
I love what you're doing with the business

91.text:
community." "Mike it's so great New York is
so safe." And I was beginning to think, "Nobody,

96.text:
absolutely nobody has the first clue who I
am," until, eventually, someone stopped, looked

104.text:
at me and said, "Hey, Cameron, Prime Minster's
Questions. We love your show." Now Freda,

118.text:
I still vividly remember that conversation
we had in Downing Street, and what you said

123.text:
to me. about not standing by, but fighting
the evils of prejudice, discrimination and

130.text:
intolerance, in Britain and around the world.
It's what the Holocaust Education Trust is

135.text:
all about, and it's why I'm here tonight.
It is a huge honour to be part of this special

141.text:
dinner and to be able to pay tribute to the
Holocaust Educational Trust (HET)'s extraordinary

145.text:
achievements over the last 25 years.
From the vision of Greville Janner and Merlyn

150.text:
Rees who set out in search of justice and
education to the War Crimes Act of 1991; the

159.text:
inclusion of Holocaust education in the history
Curriculum; the recognition for British people

166.text:
who risked their lives to save Jews during
the Holocaust; the creation of Holocaust Memorial

171.text:
Day; the training of over 1,000 teachers every
year; the chance for 70,000 young people every

180.text:
year to hear a Holocaust survivor speak; and
the 21,000 school children and teachers who

186.text:
have been able to make the journey to Auschwitz
because of the Holocaust Educational Trust

192.text:
- these are just some of remarkable achievements
of the last 25 years.

198.text:
And I pay tribute to Stephen Rubin, Paul Phillips,
David Hunt and of course Karen Pollock and

203.text:
the whole team for the extraordinary work
you do and the impact you have made. I'm delighted

219.text:
too that one of the Vice Chairmen of my party,
Richard Harrington, is also on your board.

223.text:
But there is one group of HET supporters without
whom much of this would never have been possible.

229.text:
And they are the survivors who selflessly
and tirelessly travel the length and breadth

235.text:
of the country week in, week out, to give
their testimony. Men and women who are prepared

261.text:
to relive the most harrowing moments of humanity
every day to preserve the memory of what happened

266.text:
and teach others. People who have come to
this country and rebuilt their lives, started

271.text:
businesses, in one case even become a British
Olympic weightlifting champion. And yet have

276.text:
spent hour upon hour reliving the one thing
that many people in their position would do

282.text:
anything just to try and somehow forget.
People here tonight like Harry, who couldn't

289.text:
understand why his mother pushed him out of
her house and off to the factory, when she

293.text:
was actually saving his life. Josef, who I
met earlier, who witnessed the execution of

299.text:
his mother, 4 sisters, his nephew and his
niece. And Zigi who says he just "wants people

307.text:
to learn you must never hate"
Tonight we have 28 Holocaust survivors with

313.text:
us. And I'd like to ask them to stand up so
that we can all show our appreciation for

317.text:
their courage and their extraordinary work
in supporting the Holocaust Educational Trust.

332.text:
As we've heard, tonight's dinner isn't just
about marking the achievements of the last

339.text:
25 years. It's also about meeting the challenges
of the next 25 and beyond.

343.text:
I remember first learning about the Holocaust
at school by watching "The World at War" narrated

349.text:
by Laurence Olivier. But most vividly of all,
some years later, I remember my sharp intake

354.text:
of breath and the stomach-churning feeling
of meeting a survivor and seeing for the first

359.text:
time the serial number on his arm.
For my generation this may be history -- but

364.text:
it's recent enough to feel very real. I want
my children, my grandchildren and their children

371.text:
to learn about the Holocaust too. But for
them I know it will increasingly feel more

376.text:
distant and remote. The images they will see
are black and white. They won't always have

382.text:
survivors around them telling their stories
first hand. And worse there will be some people

387.text:
-- as there are today -- who despicably try
to challenge the truth of what happened.

393.text:
So first, we need to work harder than ever
to preserve the memory of the Holocaust from

398.text:
generation to generation. And second, we need
to continue to learn and apply the lessons

404.text:
of the Holocaust to our society at home and
abroad.

408.text:
Let me take these in turn.
First, preserving the memory of the Holocaust.

413.text:
It is sickening to have to say this, but today
- even in the face of survivors going through

417.text:
the pain and suffering of retelling their
stories - there are some who try to deny that

423.text:
it ever happened.
There are some who try make excuses for it,

427.text:
who try to draw completely inappropriate parallels
with other political causes, or who try to

432.text:
suggest it somehow wasn't quite as bad as
others have said. And there are some who,

438.text:
probably with much better intentions, fall
into the trap of using loose and lazy language,

444.text:
bandying around the term Holocaust when talking
about other things.

449.text:
As a society, we need to stand up to all of
this wherever and whenever we see it. Anti-Semitism

455.text:
is not just an assault on the Jewish people
-- it is an assault on humanity. And we must

460.text:
fight it together. We need to be clear with
our children and clear in our schools: there

466.text:
are no excuses. No parallels. No softening
of the blow to human conscience of the truly

473.text:
horrific nature of what happened.
And while there are many atrocities today,

479.text:
even in some of the darkest corners of the
world, there is nothing equivalent to the

485.text:
Holocaust. The dehumanisation. The scale.
The industrial nature of what was done. Those

491.text:
haunting images of the trains arriving. The
methodological recording of what happened.

498.text:
The Holocaust stands apart as a unique moment.
It is the darkest hour of human history. And

506.text:
we must ensure that it is always remembered
in that way.

511.text:
But to do so, we must become ever more imaginative
in how we keep that memory alive. HET are

517.text:
leading the way -- and it's vital that we
support them this evening.

521.text:
Last summer, many young people will have learnt
about the Holocaust for the first time when

525.text:
they saw their England football heroes with
HET at the gates of Auschwitz. The new Ambassador's

533.text:
programme is helping thousands of young people
who have visited Auschwitz with the Trust

537.text:
- to go on sharing their knowledge with their
peers and their wider community throughout

541.text:
their lives.
The Lessons from Auschwitz programme, which

544.text:
creates those ambassadors, enables 2 students
from every school and college in the country

549.text:
to visit Auschwitz. And I'm pleased to say
that the government will support this further

554.text:
with an additional £300,000 every year.
I also intend to do my part, as Prime Minister,

569.text:
by visiting Auschwitz myself next year.
But this evening I want to ask a question.

579.text:
As we approach the 70th anniversary of the
British liberation of Bergen-Belsen in April

584.text:
2015, what more should Britain do to commemorate
and educate people about the Holocaust for

590.text:
generations to come?
Should we do more to record the memories and

594.text:
the testimony of the survivors?
Can we learn anything from the memorials and

598.text:
commemorations in other countries -- like
in America or Germany? Earlier this year on

603.text:
a visit to Berlin, I sat in the shadow of
the museum with my family and first tried

609.text:
to explain to my children the enormity of
what happened in the Holocaust.

614.text:
In Britain we have the memorial in Hyde Park,
the Holocaust Centre in Nottingham, the Wiener

619.text:
Library and the exhibition at the Imperial
War Museum. And, of course, we have the great

623.text:
work that HET is doing helping to educate
future generations.

627.text:
But at a time when Anti-Semitism is returning
in some parts of mainland Europe, it is more

632.text:
important than ever that -- as a whole country
- we do everything possible to make sure that

636.text:
the memory of the Holocaust is preserved from
generation to generation.

641.text:
So today I am asking the Chair of the Jewish
Leadership Council, Mick Davis, to assemble

645.text:
a multi-faith, cross-party national commission
representing our whole society and to investigate

651.text:
whether further measures should be taken to
ensure Britain has a permanent and fitting

656.text:
memorial and educational resource for generations
to come.

660.text:
I will chair the first meeting of this new
Commission later this year. I want it to include

665.text:
senior figures from across the Jewish community
and to work with the Board of Deputies and

669.text:
the Holocaust Educational Trust as key delivery
partners. And I will ask the Commission to

673.text:
report back to me ahead of the 70th anniversary
in 2015.

679.text:
Let me turn to the lessons of the Holocaust.
One of the reasons why the act of remembering

685.text:
matters is not just to preserve the facts
but to remind us that we must never let anything

692.text:
like it ever happen again. The horror of the
Holocaust is unique but the lessons we learn

697.text:
from it are absolutely applicable right across
our society at home and abroad.

703.text:
In particular, the lesson of not standing
by. The Holocaust did not begin with mass

712.text:
murder. It began with words, with segregation,
segmentation, restriction of employment rights

719.text:
and seizure of property. It began with pure
discrimination.

724.text:
And when we see this-- against anyone, any
group and in any form we should stand up to

729.text:
it. That means banning preachers of hate from
coming to our country, proscribing 
organisations that incite terrorism and stopping

745.text:
extremist groups from getting an audience
on our university campuses. It means universities

751.text:
themselves ensuring a clear line between free
speech which is a fundamental right, and intimidation,

761.text:
which is fundamentally wrong. And it means
a bit less of the hands-off tolerance that

768.text:
makes us too cautious, or frankly even fearful
as a society, to stand up to those who hold

773.text:
unacceptable views or pursue unacceptable
practices.

778.text:
That same vigilance of not just standing by
when our values are violated is just as important

785.text:
when it comes to our foreign policy. It's
an extraordinary human emotion but somehow

791.text:
when genocide is taking place the shame of
not acting sometimes doesn't quite register

798.text:
properly until afterwards. When we look back
at Srebrenica and Rwanda, we wonder now why

807.text:
we didn't do more at the time. When something
truly terrible happens, it's as if we put

813.text:
up a defence mechanism and try and rationalise
why we are powerless to act.

819.text:
The same could so easily be true of Syria.
You know the story of this Summer. But let

826.text:
me tell you how it felt. When I was sitting
in Cornwall on my holiday I watched the videos

832.text:
of those children being gassed to death by
President Assad's regime. I saw children's

839.text:
bodies stored in ice. Young men and women
gasping for air and suffering the most agonising

846.text:
deaths—all inflicted by weapons that have
been outlawed for nearly a century.

856.text:
And let's not forget, chemical weapons that
also pose a massive potential threat to Israel.

863.text:
So there I was facing this reality. The evidence
before our eyes. The flagrant breach of an

868.text:
international taboo against the use of chemical
weapons. The refugee crisis of our time -- in

875.text:
which nearly 500 will flee during this dinner
tonight. And a man-made humanitarian catastrophe

882.text:
where 6.8 million in Syria are in need of
humanitarian assistance but convoys simply

887.text:
can't get to them safely.
What was my instinct? It wasn't to say let's

892.text:
think of the best way to secure advantage
for my political party. It was to say what

899.text:
is the best way for my country to stand up.
Because Britain is not the sort of country

904.text:
that wants to stand by.
Of course in a complex civil war there are

908.text:
no easy answers. We cannot forget the complex
regional factors that touch on Israel's core

914.text:
interests, as they do British interests too.
And let me assure you that the safety of Israel

919.text:
will always be a fundamental concern for me.
But I felt we had to take a stand. Let's not

932.text:
pretend that Syria would now be promising
to give up its chemical weapons if we had

938.text:
just stood by and said nothing. And I'm proud
too that Britain is leading an international

943.text:
effort at the United Nations to secure unfettered
humanitarian access inside Syria and to make

949.text:
up the financial shortfall for humanitarian
aid by the time the United Nations General

953.text:
Assembly meeting takes place next week in
New York.

959.text:
With me as Prime Minister, Britain will never
stand by. We will not stand by when people

967.text:
talk with genocidal intent about the Jewish
people -- as the Iranian regime has done.

972.text:
We will not stand by as the Iranians continue
their path to nuclear weapons.

977.text:
And we will back Israel's right to defend
itself, when rockets from terrorists in Lebanon

981.text:
or Gaza fire into Israeli homes.
But so too we will speak frankly to both sides

993.text:
in supporting renewed efforts for peace. As
I said to President Abbas last week, Britain

999.text:
will do its bit in standing up to those who
make it more difficult. So yes, we will condemn

1005.text:
illegal settlement activity but so too will
we condemn incitement to terrorism and all

1010.text:
provocations that threaten the path of peace.
Last Saturday, on Yom Kippur, the victims

1018.text:
of the holocaust were remembered in Synagogues
throughout the land, during the Yizkor service.

1024.text:
But that remembrance is not just about the
past, it's about the future too.

1030.text:
As Emeritus Chief Rabbi Sacks writes in his
Yom Kippur prayer book:

1035.text:
Judaism gave two majestic ideas their greatest
religious expression: memory and hope. Memory

1043.text:
is our living connection to those who came
before us. Hope is what we hand on to the

1048.text:
generations yet to come, for when Jews
remember, they do so for the future, the place

1054.text:
where, if we are faithful to it, the past
never dies.

1059.text:
I believe that remembering for the future
is vital for us all. When I visited Yad Vashem

1066.text:
in 2006 I wrote that "We owe it to those who
died -- and those who survived -- to build

1073.text:
a world in which this can never happen again."
That is my pledge. That is why Britain will

1081.text:
remember. That is why Britain will never stand
by. And that is why I stand here as Prime

1087.text:
Minister and say to the survivors here tonight:
the past will never die and your courage will
